results.justification: The document explicitly states the research focus on team formation and its challenges, outlining the goal of exploring design considerations for positive collaborative outcomes. It also mentions the use of a priority algorithm.
Section 3 details the priority algorithm with pseudocode (Algorithm 1) and a schematic (Figure 1), providing a step-by-step description of its operation. Section 4 describes the evaluation framework.
The document mentions using real class data but does not provide a link or mention where the raw or processed datasets are publicly available.
The document states data collection involved student surveys and acknowledges potential privacy concerns implicitly by not sharing the raw data.
While the document describes the characteristics of the student data (e.g., gender distribution, GPA), a detailed data dictionary or codebook is not provided.

The document states that data was collected from university classes in 2022 and 2023, including student surveys eliciting background information. It also describes the types of data collected (e.g., timeslot availability, grades).
The document states: "We developed an open evaluation framework...The Algorithms repository is available at https://github.com/Teamable-Analytics/algorithms."
Code is shared, so justification is not needed.
The document implies that code for data preparation is included within the shared repository, as it mentions the availability of algorithms for the evaluation framework.
The document describes the use of statistical measures like cosine difference, Gini-Simpson index, and piecewise functions, indicating quantitative analysis.
The document reports metrics like project coverage, common times, intra-heterogeneity, inter-homogeneity, and solo status, which are quantifiable measures. It also discusses runtime comparisons.
The document primarily focuses on quantitative analysis and lacks in-depth subjective context or interpretation of the results.
No qualitative data analysis is performed.
The document presents results in tables (e.g., Table 1, Table 2) and figures (e.g., Figure 3, Figure 4, Figure 5, Figure 6, Figure 7, Figure 8), making the findings relatively clear.
Section 6.1 discusses limitations, including the need for more comparison algorithms and testing on more student distributions. It also acknowledges potential biases.
The document does not contain a link to a preregistration on platforms like the Open Science Foundation.
